skill.name: webapp-testing
skill.description: Toolkit for interacting with and testing local web applications using Playwright. Supports verifying frontend functionality, debugging UI behavior, capturing browser screenshots, and viewing browser logs.

security_audit.summary: Official skill from the Anthropic skills repository. Minimal audit applied with no issues observed. Safe to publish.

content.user_title: Test local web apps with Playwright
content.value_statement: Local web app testing is slow when you click and inspect by hand. This skill provides Playwright scripts and a server helper to automate checks.
actual_capabilities: Launch headless Chromium with the Playwright sync API
Wait for network idle before inspecting dynamic pages
Discover buttons, links, and inputs using locators
Capture full page screenshots to a chosen path
Capture browser console logs and write them to a file
Start one or more servers, wait for ports, run a command, then stop servers
limitations: Requires a local server or file URL you can reach
Examples assume known selectors and may need edits for your app
No built in assertions or test runner framework
Outputs are saved to local filesystem paths you provide

use_cases.title: Verify UI after changes
use_cases.description: Run a quick automated pass to confirm buttons, links, and forms render after a local build.

use_cases.title: Capture UI evidence
use_cases.description: Collect screenshots and console logs for a reproducible bug report on a staging build.

use_cases.title: Automate smoke checks
use_cases.description: Wrap a dev server and run Playwright checks in a lightweight local workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Beginner smoke check
prompt_templates.scenario: Local app is running on port 5173
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the webapp testing skill to open http://localhost:5173, wait for network idle, list visible buttons, and take a full page screenshot.

prompt_templates.title: Static HTML audit
prompt_templates.scenario: You have a local HTML file
prompt_templates.prompt: Open a local file URL for my HTML file, take a screenshot, click the main call to action, and report any errors.

prompt_templates.title: Console log capture
prompt_templates.scenario: Need browser logs after a click
prompt_templates.prompt: Navigate to my local app, click Dashboard, capture console messages, and save them to a log file.

prompt_templates.title: Multi server run
prompt_templates.scenario: Frontend and backend need to start
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the server helper to start backend on 3000 and frontend on 5173, then run a Playwright script that checks the home page.

output_examples.input: Check my local app for key UI elements and console errors.
output: Opened http://localhost:5173 and waited for network idle
Found 6 buttons, 4 links, and 3 input fields
Captured full page screenshot for review
No console errors observed during navigation

best_practices: Run the server helper with --help before use
Wait for network idle before inspecting the DOM
Close the browser at the end of each run
anti_patterns: Inspect the DOM before the page reaches network idle
Rely on vague selectors when roles or text are available
Leave servers running after the automation ends

faq.question: What platforms are compatible?
faq.answer: It works with local web apps and static HTML using Playwright in Python.

faq.question: What are the limits?
faq.answer: It needs reachable URLs and valid selectors. It does not provide built in assertions.

faq.question: How do I integrate it with my dev server?
faq.answer: Use the with_server helper to start servers and then run your Playwright script.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: The skill runs locally and writes outputs to local paths you choose.

faq.question: What if the server never becomes ready?
faq.answer: Check the port, increase the timeout, or confirm the server command runs on its own.

faq.question: How does it compare to manual testing?
faq.answer: It is faster and repeatable, but manual review is still useful for visual judgment.
